The room was clean and well maintained throughout our stay. We found the temperature in the room a bit cold (A/C maximum heating on) so two evenings we used the separate heater which was in the room. The floors were quite cold, especially in the bathroom. There are only 3 - 4 rooms / floor. Still, when anyone was walking / talking outside our room, we could really hear everything they said so the door does not keep the noise outside the room very well. The temperature was the only thing that was a bit disappointing, otherwise the hotel was great, and we would definitely stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “love the location”
Reviews.Author: BenzRana
Reviews.Content: I love the location of the hotel. Quite near MTR station & there are a lot of food and shopping choices in the vicinity. Though rooms are a bit small it is ok and not too cramp for 2 persons, has a homey feel too. It is such a pleasure too that they have plates, bowls, spoon & fork, knives and all the things you might need, even cooking appliance and microwave oven. The FREE internet access is priceless :) Would love to go back to this hotel, only wish they'd allow kids to stay with us in the studio or 2 kids to stay with us in suite rooms.

Reviews.Title: “compact and convenient”
Reviews.Author: N7tripper
Reviews.Content: Small but comfortable hotel, close to the metro for easy access to the attractions of Central and Kowloon. The room was compact but well thought out and well equipped, the staff were pleasant and helpful. The restaurant was being renovated during our stay but there are plenty of places to eat in the surrounding streets and plazas.

Reviews.Title: “HK weekend getaway”
Reviews.Author: AnnickenB
Reviews.Content: I love this place! The white interior and design in the apartment gives it a soothing and home kind of feeling to it. It's like coming "home", since the look and feel of the place is like it could be your home. Even though I only stayed here for 4 days and 3 nights. I wouldn't change a thing. Jia Boutique Hotel is easy to find, and you can easily get around HK from it. Even for people whom haven't been there before. Just use the MTR. You should all see for yourself and book in here on the next trip to HK!

Reviews.Title: “A wonderful base from which to explore Hong Kong”
Reviews.Author: burdekin
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent seven wonderful nights at this hotel, in a studio room, and could not fault it. The staff were very friendly and very helpful at all times, obviously enjoying their work environment. As is the norm for Hong Kong hotels, the room was not large, but it was very well laid out with a host of features - plenty of storage space, free internet (cables and adaptor plug provided), TV that rotated 360 degrees, even a small kitchette with hotplate and microwave. The continental style breakfast laid on in the foyer area provided a pleasant start to the day, and the free evening wine was very much appreciated, and provided a forum to exchange tips withy other travellers - unfortunately we never got to enjoy the afternoon tea and cakes! The route A11 bus from the airport dropped us off only a short block away (at Sugar Street) for only HK$40 each. The MTR station was only a short walk away, as were buses and trams. There was a restaurant in the building that we didn't use, as well as a number of nearby restaurants that provided a room delivery service to the hotel, but there was no shortage of eating places of all descriptions within a couple of blocks. A bonus were the free washing machines and dryers on Floor 2 and complimentary access to a nearby fitness centre.

Reviews.Title: “Chic, modern, and comfy in a great location! Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: JennyPennyLouisville
Reviews.Content: We loved this hotel and would stay again! The hotel was beautifully designed and very clean, with a free bottled water, espresso/coffee, and soft drinks available 24-7. The rooms were medium-sized and nicely done with a comfortable bed and nice linens. The free continental breakfast was excellent and they have free washers and dryers for use. The hotel was a 4 minute walk to the metro and was within 3 minutes to the huge mall and shopping area. French restaurant nearby, but we enjoyed eating near the outdoor escalators in Central and Soho most. The concierge and front desk helped with directing us--service was excellent. Our fave places to eat: Eat Right (off escalators), iCaramba (mexican) and Hong Kong Brew Company (great food & beer!) Asked the concierge for directions and she looked it up on the internet, wrote the name and address in Chinese, and gave us a map!

Reviews.Title: “Great experience”
Reviews.Author: anonymous77
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a little gem. And when I say little, I certainly mean it. Everything from the rooms, the lobby, the elevator foyer, the hallways and even the chairs are small. But it was staffed with very helpful, well-informed employees who exuded calm competence. We appreciated the morning continental breakfast - nice selection of cereals, fruit, breads and yogurt. As has been said in earlier reviews, the rooms are small but well designed and I think that rooms in HK are generally very petite as we also stayed at Langham Place and the rooms there were also small (tho that hotel was a much larger and more full service experience). Causeway Bay is a great, bustling spot perfect for touring the city. There are lots of both luxury and not so luxury shopping options and the streets surrounding the hotel are full of local residents and tons of dining options. I would definitely recommend this hotel for guests who do no require over the top 5-star luxury but who do appreciate cleanliness, good design and an excellent value in a great HK neighborhood. Note that we didn't try the in room dining options or the restaurant that just opened in the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome Boutique hotel in the middle of Chaos!”
Reviews.Author: Captivemarket
Reviews.Content: My partner and I stayed at JIA HONG KONG for 5 Nights and loved the entire experience. We stayed in Standard Room, and although small (as MOST HK Hotels are), it suited us perfectly. Great Design, Great Service and Great Location. Excellent Self Service Breakfast in the morning as well as Wine and Cheese at night. Quiet and Clean. The staff were FANTASTIC. The Restaurant (OPIA) and Bar is EXCELLENT. Highly Recommended!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Small rooms but excellent service and added touches”
Reviews.Author: TO_traveller69
Reviews.Content: We loved the little touches - continential breakfast in lobby, unlimited softdrinks and water 24hrs a day and FREE WINE in the lobby in the evenings. The hotel is swanky and funky, its only downfall being that the rooms are a bit small (expected for HK) but well equipped. Suprisingly quite on the higher floors.

Reviews.Title: “Hip Hong Kong Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Bulakbol
Reviews.Content: I found JIA while looking for smaller but nicer accommodations in Hong Kong. The studio room was a bit too small for my needs but it was tolerable, maybe because the bed was too big for the room space. If I am not mistaken, the studio room is about 30 sqm but it had a receiving area plus a tiny kitchen in it too. Bathroom size is okay. I just had some problems with the water pressure but it was addressed immediately. I found the hotel nice and hip but it felt a bit cramped. The hallways looked dark and it was also dark and eerie inside the elevator. If you're claustrophobic or the type of person who demands space, then this property may not be for you. The breakfast selection is limited though they were all good. The location of the hotel is excellent, it's just a few minutes walk to some of the nicer malls in Causeway Bay. If you're coming from the airport, you may take the Airport Express to Hong Kong station then board the H2 shuttle bus and get off the Regal Hong Kong Hotel. JIA is just 50m down the road.

Reviews.Title: “Alright.”
Reviews.Author: Amster_k
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Jia in one of their studio rooms (type 2) for one night this past weekend. I've read the other reviews and were prepared for small rooms, but what really erked me was the fact that the entire hotel (and my room) had this faint smell of food- as though the hotel's ventilation system was connected to a nearby Chinese restaurant or something. Putting aside the very small room- almost like a larger dorm room- and the ever-present smell, the furnitures were quite pretty, the bed was comfortable, the breakfast, while limited in choice was fresh and of good-quality, and the staff were accomodating, helpful and polite. While I wish I could rate this hotel higher, the very cramped and dark room/hotel (everything seemed cramped- the lobby, elevators, hallways, etc) and the erksome smell (don't tell me it was an oriental room-spray) prevent me from warmly recommending the Jia to others.

Reviews.Title: “Charmed by Jia”
Reviews.Author: Heather079
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from Jia and will definitely stay there if we visit Hong Kong again. The hotel is pretty and the standard studios, whilst small, are exceptionally well designed to make up for it. The only negative is the unusually noisy air conditioning which is situated directly above the bed in the studios. Every night sounded like a storm was raging outside - to the extent that the night a typhoon actually hit Hong Kong we didnt realise. However, everything else was excellent, particularly the charming and friendly staff who made us feel at home the minute we arrived and were unbelievably polite to the many guests complaining that the city was on shutdown due to the force 8 typhoon (on shutdown because it was dangerous to travel - although of course hotel staff are obliged to come in!). The restaurant / bar is currently closed for refurbishment and I wondered whether that accounted for the particularly homey feel, and the relatively low rate we got by booking direct through the hotel's web page. Jia's location is very good - not in the heart of central but in a neon-crazy, buzzy shopping area that is very close to the amazing MTR and within walking distance of wan chai ferry terminal. The street directly opposite the hotel is packed with local, cheap, good places to eat, although we didnt stumble on any bars in this area to repair to afterwards. If you stay do use Jia's own recommendations - a booklet in the hotel suggested an excellent place for cheap, wonderful dim sum (harbour city) and Hutong, a lovely place for a special meal with views.

Reviews.Title: “Jia Hip AND Good Value -- Who Knew?”
Reviews.Author: KittyChan
Reviews.Content: I first stayed at Jia last year, and I've been back twice (most recently for two nights in early April '08). There's a lot to like about this small (50-some studio and suite apartments) boutique hotel, and if you're an independent traveler seeking style, comfort, and value in an HK hotel, I highly recommend the Jia. Hotel: Jia occupies a typically slender, nondescript high-rise building in Causeway Bay. While its residential-flat origins are apparent, the building's makeover works very well, from the cozy and functional lobby area to the two efficient lifts servicing the 20 floors. Rooms: I've stayed in both basic room types -- studio and suite -- and I come firmly down on the side of fellow travellers who found the rooms spacious and well thought out. Both formats make excellent use of space, and the Starck-designed furnishings and decor, while not high-end, are attractive and grow on one with successive stays at the Jia. The studio, at about 34 sq. m., is fine for the single traveller. The suite, double the size of the studio, basically adds space to the open living/dining/kitchen area while maintaining the same intimate sleeping and bathroom areas. Bathrooms in both layouts are done in a very smart grey-and-white marble; if you want a full bath, however, stay elsewhere. I was fine with the large walk-in shower, and the rest of the bathroom -- especially the clear-glass sink and bevel-mirrored medicine cabinet -- is visually and functionally appealing. Both layouts include a kitchenette; I don't cook when I travel, especially to HK, but it's a good touch to have basic kitchen amenities for urban-hipster families who may be more cooking-inclined than I. As others have noted, the windows in Jia's rooms are one feature that didn't get upgraded in the building's transformation from flats to "boutique" accommodations. They're single-paned, but I found the noise from the street, particularly on the higher floors on which I've stayed, minimal. Jia provides blinds, shears, and blackout curtains on all room windows; and these effectively reduce most street noise. The rooms' lighting and other electronic features (TV/DVD, A/C) take a bit of time to become user-friendly, but everything works well and looks good. One minor nitpick: the smallish (but high-quality) flat-screen TV is fixed in place: it faces the living/sitting area rather than the sleeping area, and it can't be swivelled to face the bed. No matter; one shouldn't be watching much TV while visiting HK, anyway. Quick note on the A/C: My stays at Jia have all coincided with warm or hot weather in HK, and the A/C (just one unit, even in the suites, if I remember correctly) is excellent: it has a high-power setting, which quickly cools the room to the point where it can be chilly. I like that, and I even like the continuous ventilation sounds of the A/C when it's on: good white noise while sleeping. Again, though, some travellers might find the A/C a bit too efficient, but it's a high-tech unit that probably heats the room as well in colder seasons. Two other nice Jia room touches: free local calls and internet service. Lobby/refreshments/front desk: Much happens in Jia's small lobby. The tiny reception desk, which is always staffed by at least one black-clad person, can get overwhelmed if more than a few people are simultaneously checking in our out or looking for transportation or restaurant-reservation assistance. But the property is small enough that this is not a big problem. The lobby has more Starck furniture, some comfortable, some not. There is a long, narrow table with high stools; this is the best bet for properly consuming Jia's complimentary continental breakfast (good if limited selection of fruits, breads, yoghurts, and beverages). I've not availed myself of Jia's complimentary happy-hour wine bar, but the small lobby refrigerator is always stocked with free soft drinks. (I think the San Pellegrino is a particularly welcome feature.) Restaurant/bar/dining: I've not yet eaten at Opia, Jia's hightly rated restaurant, but I plan to rectify that oversight during my next stay. Opia and the adjacent bar are, of course, very stylish, and the bar has a good snack/light-food menu as well. Location: Depending on what's important to you, Jia's location is either so-so or great. For me, it's the latter: the hotel is just one block away from the MTR, which will get you anywhere you need to go in HK. For getting to Central or other HK Island spots, Jia's Causeway Bay location is a very convenient and cheap starting point for HK's plentiful taxis. Causeway Bay is also a lively and interesting neighborhood, with lots of shopping, dining, and (local) people-watching possibilities. And, again, it's only a very short taxi, MTR, or Star Ferry ride to other interesting parts of HK. Reservations/booking: This is the one area where I hope to see improvement by Jia. Until a few months ago, one could not reserve Jia rooms directly from the website; one either had to call or e-mail the hotel. While Jia's website now features (ihotelier-provided) online booking capability, the website is not secure (at least in all of the different web browsers -- IE, Safari, Firefox -- I have tried), so I have either used Expedia or direct contact to make reservations at Jia. A warning if you use Expedia, as I did for my last stay: Jia apparently doesn't receive confirmation of Expedia or other travel-agency reservations until a minimum of 24 hours after the booking is made. I found this out the hard way during my last stay, when I arrived at Jia at 2 a.m. only to find that the hotel had no record of my booking -- two nights in a suite -- which I'd made just the day before. The receptionist explained the booking-delay possibility and then added that the hotel was pretty much full for the weekend. He did find an available room, but no suite was available that first night, so I ended up taking an available studio. By way of apology, the receptionist offered a complimentary limo from the hotel to HKIA for my departure, which I found a more-than-satisfactory response to the problem. Bottom line, I suppose, is to double-check with Jia before arrival, whatever the means of booking one uses. Value: For such a cute, hip property, Jia also represents a rare lodging value in HK. Whether booking directly with the hotel or via an online travel service such as Expedia or Orbitz, Jia's promotional rates make the rooms something of a bargain. Often, the difference in price between a studio and a suite is fairly small: I've seen as little as HKD 400, which makes the suite (at 700 sq. m.) probably the best suite bargain of any decent-or-better hotel property in HK. When I first stayed at Jia, in the summer of 2007, I booked a studio for one night at HKD 1,600 and was given a suite for that price. Even without an upgrade, that rate struck me as a good value; getting a suite for that price -- very nice. Finally, it's worth checking Jia's website at least several times before you book, as rates seem to be carefully calibrated to occupancy rates (both actual and antcipated), and you may see a drop in price from one day to the next. Conclusion: Overall, I rate Jia as an excellent accommodation option in HK. It's probably more suited to younger, urban-oriented travelers, but it represents a stylish, comfortable value for pretty much anyone. Give it a try.

Reviews.Title: “Suites are great”
Reviews.Author: ozman666
Reviews.Content: Have read a few reviews stating that the rooms are small... I stayed here in Jan 08 on 22nd floor one bedroom suite and it was far from small. Fitted with small but funtional kitchen (who dines in in HK anyway), large lounge, day bed room, big bathroom and a perfect sized bedroom being that you only need the bed. I wish i had bought the CD that was the sound track to many drunken returns. Location was great, near all the nice shops and just a short cab right ride from the heart of the city. I would return for sure!

Reviews.Title: “Great city, lovely hotel”
Reviews.Author: tylerpaul
Reviews.Content: We spent 2 nights at the end of Feb 08 here. Hong Kong is manic and such fun, we loved it! As for Jia, we had a great experience there also. Not sure where some of the bad reviews are coming from. OK maybe it's a bit noisy at lower levels and breakfast is too cramped for more than 6 people but as regular travellers we're used to sleeping with ear plugs and as for breaky - take it to your room, problem solved! Service excellent, friendly and competent, they made an effort for us finding great restaurants and things for do. The hotel itself has put a lot of effort into its style/apprearance and it works. The rooms are small but make good use of the space with kitchenette, sofa and curtained-off bed area. It's modern and fresh. It's also v well located, v close to Times Square. Overall, I definitely recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Design Over Function”
Reviews.Author: InkLondon
Reviews.Content: This is a classic case of too much focus on how the place looks and not enough on what customers actually want. And don't misunderstand, I am in my 30's, love design and usually like individual hotels. The issues: - 1) no hot water in the bathroom sink for 3 days 2) no room service but a poor delivery service with only 5 snacks (and no vegetarian) after 10.30pm. I found myself walking eth streets looking for a take-away at 10.45pm - the hotel wouldn't send out for me. 3) a free but very limited breakfast on a shared table that you can't get your legs under. Or you can sit in reception on a plastic stool with a plate on your lap. 4) A restaurant that closes early if its not busy and won't let you take food to your room. 5) A TV/DVD music system that is super complicated to work (you change the tv channel with the dvd controller and the volume with a different control) 6) Freezing cold if there in winter This place shoudl be billed as serviced apartments but not a fully functioning hotel. Stay here to party for a few days but NOT if you're on business and you expect things to work. Style over substence.

Reviews.Title: “Chic and clean but noisy”
Reviews.Author: Audrey-Jane
Reviews.Content: JIA is beautifully designed and had some really nice touches. The studio suites are small but I'm a solo traveller so it suited me. If you're a couple or a family, go for a larger size apartment or suite. The interiors are nice, diaphanous net to the bedroom area, really comfortable bed, wardrobes that light up when you open them, marble lined bathroom. And the house service was brilliant, ecah day I returned to an immaculately clean room. The reception staff were friendly and helpful too. They gave me the tip I was looking for - I'm a fanatical runner and Victoria Park is nearby but go early! Hong Kong gets busy as soon as it gets remotely light and the park becomes full - there is a small 600m track but if you want a good hours burn, do 8 circuits round the park itself but be careful of the bumping into the tai chi crowds. Back to JIA and location. I'm not a big foodie so I ate in my room but it's well located for foodie types who want to hang out at traditional/local food places in Jardine's Bazzaar or go more central. The best supermarket is in Times Square on the basement level (go down the circular staircase in the main department store). Transport is the MTR and there's a station 2 mins walk away and negotiating it all is so easy - get yourself an Octopus card from the station and you're away! My only complaints are that there is NO SOUNDPROOFING inside or out so if my neighbour was on the phone near my wall, I could hear him. The traffic noise is constant pretty much too and I could smell all the various cooking smells from the street outside. It got a bit chilly too but there is a heater and I am someone prone to feeling the slightest cold. I agree if you're a first timer and want a bit of pampering, then perhaps it's not for you but if you want to run around and explore and have a nice clean comfortable base to come back to (oh, with flat screen TV with pretty much all the main cable channels), then JIA is perfect

Reviews.Title: “overhyped”
Reviews.Author: akotova
Reviews.Content: It's not a hotel . It's an apartment building with noisy small rooms and no heating. The interior was ok and the service was satisfactory

Reviews.Title: “Very noisy ... busy streets ...single pane windows”
Reviews.Author: slaughterbeach
Reviews.Content: What the JIA spent on design it certainly did not spend on construction. This is a very noisy hotel. All the street noise is transmitted through single pane windows and through air shaft in the bath. We have had to change rooms after being told it wouldn't make a difference. It didn't. Free Internet and breakfast certainly a plus but not worth a good nights sleep. Staff is very helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location and boutique hotel”
Reviews.Author: techfriend
Reviews.Content: The Jia is a young hip and cool place to stay in HK. There are lots of places to eat on Irving. It is only a 2-3 blocks away from SOGO and the MTR. There are some great shops in the Causeway Bay area, all within walking distance. Times Square is about a quick 10-12 minute walk away. If shopping is your thing, its hard to beat the convenience and the price of this hotel. The staff are all courteous and helpful. The free continental breakfast every morning is a nice touch, don't forget the fresh OJ. There is also complimentary gym passes to California Fitness close to Times Square. Good facilities and not too busy. There is also a laundry place right behind the hotel. Only $28 hkd to do a bag of laundry and you get it back in an hour. Just make sure you separate your whites and colours! As you will guess, I highly recommend this place to stay. Also be sure to check out LKF if you like your drinks. Its a fun happening area almost every night.

Reviews.Title: “Love, love, loved Jia”
Reviews.Author: anonnymouseSingapore
Reviews.Content: Just back from a long weekend in Hong Kong where we stayed at the Jia. I was almost reluctant to write a review for Tripadvisor as I liked the feeling that we had discovered a little gem and don't want too many people to find out about it - but fair's fair, I probably wouldnt' have booked to stay there without reading other people's reviews on here! I totally loved Jia - it was so refreshing not to be in a standard hotel room in a city - we booked a studio room and was expecting it to be much smaller than it was - it actually worked out to be quite spacious by the time they had fitted in a study area, living area, kitchenette and sleeping area - very clever use of space. We really felt like we were staying in a very cool studio flat rather than a hotel. It was also VERY cool - very stylish. I loved the lobby with its quirky designer furniture and all the little designer touches around the hotel and rooms (the light fittings, mirrors etc). The location was great, a 2mins walk to Causeway Bay MTR station which is only 3 stops from central. A taxi home from Lan Kwai Fong took only 10mins and was pretty cheap. We got back from a bar in Tsim Sha Tsui in 30mins door to door, using the MTR. (My top tip - if you get the Airport Express train into town from the airport, there is a free shuttle bus that takes you to major hotels - one of them is the Regal Hong Kong which is just opposite the Jia) The staff were really friendly and helpful, flagged down a taxi for us to get to the Airport Express station, helped me with my luggage, showed us round. Continental breakfast was included and is help-yourself in the lobby. Cable internet access was included in the room and they provided adapter and necessary cabling. The bar was very cool although it's a shame they don't have a no-smoking policy as we had to leave one night as it was sooo smoky in there, quite unpleasant. All in all I loved this place and will definitely stay here again when I come back to Hong Kong.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, good for non first-timers to Hong Kong”
Reviews.Author: leungv
Reviews.Content: My family and I stayed at JIA for a week this past September in one of their penthouse units, which is a two-level unit with two bedrooms, two baths, kitchen, dining room and living room. It was definitely spacious and a good value compared with booking two traditional hotel rooms in Hong Kong of this property class. A few comments: 1) The hotel is in a very central location in HK (Causeway Bay), meaning it is close to a lot of public transportation and shopping, but it's not really a "tourist" area. The hotel, given it's more service apartment-oriented hospitality does not have a big concierge team to speak of. I would definitely recommend this place more for folks who are not visiting Hong Kong for the first time. 2) Related to the first point, the hotel is located at the corner of two very busy streets that DO NOT ALLOW CARS TO STOP between the hours of 7am to 7pm. The hotel (which used to be a serviced apartment complex) does NOT have a driveway, which means if you are arriving during the day, with any sort of luggage, you will need to have your car stop about a block away on a side street and get someone to help you move your bags in. Again, back to my first point about how this is better for a non first time visitor because you will be more likely to take advantage of the vast public transportation options as opposed to taking cabs all the time. 3) The hotel has a great "mini bar" in the lobby that provide free non-alcoholic beverages all day. Continental breakfast, tea time snacks, and wine hour is also provided at various times of day. This was a great plus. 4) For folks with families, i definitely recommend the penthouse suites. They have full dining rooms and kitchens and even a washer and dryer, which is wonderful for extended stays. 5) Opia, the restaurant there was fairly decent if a bit on the pricey side. Overall, being a HK expat, I think I would stay at the hotel again given it's convenient location and home-like amenities. However, if you're looking for tradition 5-star pampering and hotel amenities, I would recommend other places such as the Mandarin Oriental or Four Seasons.

Reviews.Title: “A little NY in HKK at Jia Boutique hotel”
Reviews.Author: sylviaNyc
Reviews.Content: Jia Boutique hotel is a fantastic alternative to giant luxury hotels in Hong Kong, it is modern, small, stylish(Philippe Starck design) and personable. Great location as well in Causeway bay. Fabulous restaurant is right downstairs and has a good barscene at night. I would absolutely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Like having a cool apartment in Hong Kong”
Reviews.Author: Daisy5879
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Jia during a 2-night layover in Hong Kong and really enjoyed the hotel. Jia is in a great location. It's in the heart of Causeway Bay, which is a full of shops and restaurants (some high-end places, some chains, some curios) that stay open late into the night. It's right near the MTR, which can take you to Kowloon or Central in one or two stops. The price was also pretty reasonable - we booked the suite on Expedia for not much more than $200 US a night. As for the hotel itself, we were very happy with the space. The lobby is fancy but not over-the-top, and purposefully lacks all of the bells and whistles of a big chain hotel. Our suite felt like a trendy apartment in NYC, complete with plasma TV in the living room, great sound system, small kitchen, sitting area, spacious marble bathroom, and tiny but functional bedroom. Everything was very clean and sharp. The hotel provides a continental breakfast in the lobby and we we brought up lots of good fruit, cereal and coffee both mornings and ate at the kitchen table, just like we would at home. They also leavel snacks, juice and coffee/tea in the lobby so you can help yourself when you please without dealing with room service. The Jia strikes an interesting balance between luxury, boutique, and efficiency. There's no gym or pool or anything like that, and there aren't teams of porters to help you with your luggage, but the staff was really nice and helpful, the in-house restaurant (Opia) is super-cool, and no detail was overlooked. If you're looking to be doted upon, Jia isn't the hotel for you. But if you're looking for a really cool spot to feel at home while exploring Hong Kong, or if you're just sick of all the hype at big resort hotels, it might be the perfect choice.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty much my favourite hotel ever”
Reviews.Author: Jumbone
Reviews.Content: I can't recommend this place highly enough. Honestly, my two stays here have been faultless. The rooms are spotless and amazingly well appointed, and full of superb touches - great TV and sound system, gorgeous and quirky furniture, great a/c, comfy bed - even the toiletries are good. Free broadband (wireless the first time, cable only the second), and a desk to use your laptop on. And space! Anyone who's stayed in Hong Kong knows how valuable this is, and the Jia really delivers. The service is impeccable, and the staff bend over backwards to help. The continental breakfast features really good pastries, and the coffee doesn't disappoint either. The bar is great, and the restaurant is out of this world, though it's very expensive - but I foresee M. Michelin awarding a star sometime soon. It's not cheap, but incredibly competitive by Hong Kong standards. I am gushing I know, but I have no connection to this hotel: it genuinely felt like a home from home, and if I can afford it I'm never going to stay anywhere else in Hong Kong. Simply superb.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent boutique hotel in a great location”
Reviews.Author: scotthumphries
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for 4 nights with my partner last August on our way to Europe. Like most people, I was initially attracted to the hotel because of its Phillip Starck design, and it certainly did not disappoint on that score, but its famous designer does somewhat overshadow the fact that this is a great little hotel in every way. We stayed in a studio, which was tiny but very cleverly designed and very comfortable. My only note is that for a fairly recent hotel I was surprised that the marble in the bathroom was rusted. But this certainly did not detract from the amenity of the room. It was very comfortable and quiet. Staff were excellent, as one expects in HK. We ate at one of the hotel's two restaurants and it was fine. The free breakfast and afternoon wine at the large communal table in the lobby is a nice touch and does make you feel a bit more like you are in a home than a hotel. It also gives you an opportunity for fun people watching - the hotel's guests seemed to primairly be well-heeled young people when we were there. The hotel's best point, though, has to be its location. We'd previously stayed in Kowloon and Central and they're fun, but Causeway Bay literally bustles all night long. There are lots of cheap eats and great shopping around the area, and the MRT station is just a short walk from the hotel. Would definitely recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Always nice to come back to Jia...”
Reviews.Author: Arturas
Reviews.Content: This was my second time at Jia in Hong Kong. And I loved to be back. People working at Jia are friendly and very helpfull whenever you need help. Hotel rooms at Jia made me feel being home while away...Very comfortable bed, great shower and if you want you even make your own breakfast using small kitchen unit... There are wash and dry machines available to wash your clothes. The only thing I miss at Jia is a gym ( but they do offer complimentary entrance to the gym very close from Jia self). Breakfast room is small and have small choice of food but good enought to start the day! I will be back....

Reviews.Title: “Nice boutique hotel”
Reviews.Author: jhtravel
Reviews.Content: Pros - very clean newly designed rooms, great location for shopping and sightseeing on Hong Kong.there is a highly rated bar and restaurant -Opia attached to the hotel and you can get room service. Open plan suite layout was good - although quite small (but perfect as a base for a slightly longer stay in Hong Kong).Hotel staff friendly and helpful. Cons - this is a boutique hotel so don't expect the same level of service/faciltiies (eg gym, bars etc ) that you get in other hotels. Area is not as central or swish as some of the other high end hotels in hong kong (Causeway Bay rather than central) - it is closer to serviced apartments than luxury hotel. Bathroom was a little on the small side. Taxi drop off/pick up difficult as no cantonese name (tell them to go to Regal Hong Kong just across the road) but this is a minor issue

Reviews.Title: “Cosy, homey hotel”
Reviews.Author: Chocolatte
Reviews.Content: Langham Place was fully booked during my business trip to Hk last week. So I decided to go for JIA after reading so much about it. Thought it will be a nice change from large hotels. Indeed, overall I'm very satisfied with JIA. I choose to stay in their spacious 1-bedroom suite as I like to have lots of space to move around. The suite was lovely, not in a posh way, but rather in a practical, contemporary sense. Bathroom is small and there's no bathtub but it is adequate since I don't really have time this round to enjoy long soaks in the bath. Service was very good. Everytime I needed a cab, the concierge would go and hail one for me. Later on, I also discover that causeway bay mtr station is just a couple of minutes' walk away.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely sanctuary in busy HongKong”
Reviews.Author: redmagnolia
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a studio suite and a 1bedroom apartment suite on our way to and from Europe. The studio suite was quite small but so compact and well designed with a mini kitchenette, marble bathroom and flat screen tv. It also had excellent a/c and very good value room service from Y bistro downstairs in the hotel. On our week long stay in a 1br suite, there were a few problems. The a/c in the bedroom smelled a little foul of pollution and despite a very prompt response from the hotel management in cleaning the filter, the smell never went away entirely during our stay. The 1 br apt is much larger and well worth the money (HKD 1995+ taxes) incl. a simple but adequate continental brekkie. The only problem being in a hotel of 100 rooms, there really wasn't enough space provided to sit down properly. There is one small dining room and a long bench with really high stools that are were uncomfortable as they were impractical. The free cakes provided during the afternoon and a few bottles of wine (no beers or spirits that we saw) were provided for happy hr, which were nice touches. Unfortunately the room service menu was reduced significantly when the hotel closed the Y bistro (permanently I think). The Hotel provided great service and the rooms were always cleaned to a very high standard, however it was starting to show its age with its white (why white?) rugs on the floor appearing quite stained. It is still an expensive choice in HongKong but provides a lovely sanctuary. Location was good with many cheap eateries like Mak's Noodles and good shopping. For bars, etc try Wyndham st in Central.

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel, without view or pool, and a bit expensive”
Reviews.Author: cm3
Reviews.Content: we stayed in the penthouse of this hotel for 5 nights. we were3 adults. it was nice. u had ur own kitchen, dining table for 8, washer/dryer, 3 lcd tv's, dvd players, and comfi beds and 2 good size bathrooms. it wasnt cheap comparing to 5 star hotels actually the same price. but u dont have pool, no view at all, simple continental breakfast( which was more then enough to start u up), no 24 hour room service. i liked that there is a place down with water and joices and some cakes all day free. the location is ok. close to metro but its in the crowded and cheap part of the town. overal ok but with the price im giving i would stay in 5 star hotel with harbour view and pool.

Reviews.Title: “Great pleasant place”
Reviews.Author: SoEtFlo
Reviews.Content: A stop for a honeymoon trip, pleasant and peaceful atmosphere. THe rooms a rea really convenient. It is exactly like if you had your own appartment in the center of HK. The decoration is really hype, good atmosphere, you can go with children as the room are quite spacious (at least the one we had). We recommend

Reviews.Title: “Hip, Happenin', and Hospitable”
Reviews.Author: StefanG
Reviews.Content: THE AREA Jia Boutique Hotel is a short walk from the Causeway Bay subway station as well as some main streetcar lines, so it's easy to get to from the "central" areas of Hong Kong. Particularly after work hours, the hotel's neighborhood teems with HK shoppers. We found a Citibank ATM a block away, which was useful. One reviewer wrote in Sept. 2005 that "the hotel is relatively new so a lot of cab drivers don't know where it is." Well, one year later our taxi driver hadn't heard about the hotel either. After you check in the hotel gives you a handy card with directions and locations written in Chinese to help you find your way back. It would be useful if they provided a scanned copy of that card on their website so you could print it out before your arrival. (Hotels and ryokans often do that in Japan, which helps out taxi drivers there.) THE ROOM Despite the heat and humidity outdoors (it was August), our room maintained a decent temperature (which we adjusted as necessary). Our queen-sized bed was firm but not uncomfortably so, and the quilt was pretty warm, so we actually turned up the air conditioning to avoid feeling overheated in the middle of the night. We were on the fifth floor and did hear light traffic noise below us on occasion but it didn't bother us enough to consider changing rooms. The important thing is that during the evening, the streets seemed quiet enough for us to get plenty of sleep. (It might be a different story if I tried to catch some shut-eye during the middle of the day.) Our room was small (about 450 sq. ft.) but with the desk, cabinets, and shelves recessed in the walls, the floor space was big enough to walk around without bumping into everything. The only problem was finding room to place our two suitcases; but that's a problem with all small hotels. The bathroom is all marble and indirect lighting (not the best for applying makeup or shaving) but the shower pressure was strong and the robes quite delightful. The LG flat-screen TV was a nice touch, as was the DVD/CD unit. The front desk offered English-language DVDs for borrowing, and the selection wasn't half-bad: a mixture of mainstream and art-house movies. Hong Kong television (or at least the room's cable TV) is pretty good anyway, and a lot of it is in English, so we didn't miss out on our entertainment needs. THE KITCHEN Other reviewers have commented on the free beverages available in the lobby -- there was free water in the room too. We loved our little kitchen. Take-out from Y's restaurant next door was delivered within 30 minutes and they didn't charge the typical arm-and-leg prices that hotels charge for room service. Y's range of Asian, Indian, American food was pretty impressive: coconut grilled stingray, wonton soup, spicy green mango salad, roasted Mediterranean vegetables, beef or veggie burger, wasabi beer battered fish with dashi chips, pizza, fried rice, green chicken curry, etc. We ate the food on the hotel's wonderful, square-shaped china dishes. They packed a lot into that kitchenette: two-burner electric stove, microwave oven, and a set of dishes, glasses, wine glasses, silverware, bowls, etc. for (in our case) two people. We stored leftovers in the small fridge and then reheated them later. It was somewhat challenging to balance the dishes on our laps or the small coffee tables in front of the couch, but we managed. BREAKFAST The complimentary breakfast was pretty good for "continental breakfast" fare, although after a few days, the same starts to get old -- but that can happen anywhere if they don't change what they offer. Still, they had a good selection of yogurt, fruit (strawberries, apples, bananas, kiwi, grapefruit -- not sure how I'd have eaten a grapefruit), cereal, toast, juice, and jam. Lots of coffee and hot water for tea, too. Hard-boiled eggs would be a nice addition to the menu, if only to provide some protein amid all the usual carbs. Free newspapers (International Herald-Tribune plus some Chinese papers) were an added bonus. Even though this did not bother us personally, the breakfast serving area in the lobby is quite cramped. I don't know how a dozen guests would be able to navigate that area at once, let alone find a place to sit down to eat breakfast. By luck we pretty much had the place to ourselves, besides a couple other guests. Once or twice we carried food to our rooms for variety's sake (trays would have helped, as carrying plates and cups/glasses into the elevator invites certain disaster). We were usually out when they had their free afternoon wine service in the lobby but a couple times we were there to enjoy the wine, which was actually quite good. SERVICE The customer service was excellent. We asked them many questions about where to eat, how to get to places, etc. and they always answered us with a smile and a determination to provide us with the most complete, helpful information. The staff was always impeccably dressed too (uniforms designed by Shanghai Tang, our Frommer's Guide informed us). We had informed them beforehand of our early arrival (8 AM) and they were very accommodating. A room was available immediately. When we left six days later, they held our luggage for several hours after check-out until we departed Hong Kong later that day. ONLY COMPLAINT This is fairly minor but the lobby's background music became tiring after a while because it was so repetitive. It's a very hip, modern collage of techno lounge music (probably not the most precise description) and they play it seemingly 24/7. The same tunes, and loudly. (You can play the same music in the room too, thanks to the CD they provide, available for purchase.) It's OK stuff, but it would have been nice to enjoy a morning of quietude now and then. There was a table in a small side room to sit down at and watch TV but the lobby's soundtrack overpowered the broadcast. At first we were pretty impressed by these decorative trappings, but after a few days they started to give us the feeling of perpetually being on stage. But this quibble doesn't prevent me from recommending Jia highly to others.

Reviews.Title: “Jia is fab!”
Reviews.Author: World_Shopper1
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Jia for our week's vacation in Hong Kong and absolutely loved it - rooms are spacious, white and cool with funky touches (loved the hotel's CD). Breakfast buffet is good and the adjacent Ys 'bistro' serves great Asia/fusion food. Staff are friendly and helpful plus the location is just great - Causeway Bay is non-stop shopping and restaurants, plus the MTR station is a 2 minute walk from the hotel. If you're a Malmaison fan you'll find this a home from home!

Reviews.Title: “Funky and Friendly”
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Jia for 4 nights with our 6 year old son. We had a suite, which was more of a bijou apartment, with a kitchenette and plenty of storage. We had a wonderful stay and thoroughly recommend it - funky, friendly & charming with simple but stylish decor and very thoughtful attention to detail. Grab the small "Luxe Guide to Hong Kong" in your room - tells you everything you need to know! We ate at "Y" which was relaxed and casual but "Opia" does not accept children. Simple but plentiful buffet breakfast and excellent takeaway-style room service. We have previously stayed in the big, bland 5star business hotels in HK but preferred Jia for a more authentic experience. There are still more Gucci concessions than can be healthy within moments of the front door so shopaholics will not miss out. Do go to Disneyland - small but perfectly formed and in a beautiful setting. We found this hotel via the excellent Tablet Hotels website (--) highly recommend it for more of the same.

Reviews.Title: “Overrated”
Reviews.Author: Nessie_the_Monster
Reviews.Content: Rooms are too small, breakfast is boring, location is so-so and for the same rate you can get much better options.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous dahhlings”
Reviews.Author: JJ-travels
Reviews.Content: Beautiful lobby, beautiful rooms, great amenities, could plug our ipod into the tv/ surround sound system and chill out. Loved the free soft drinks all day plus cocktail hour - free wine - always good! Staff extremely friendly, couldn't ask for more. Our room on 9th floor was a bit noisy from buses etc below and they changed us to a quieter higher floor with no quibbles at all. Room service from the ground floor restaurant was great and i think their food was better (and much cheaper) than the rated ozzy chef, ? restaurant (cant remember name) on the 1st floor. we would definately come back here again.

Reviews.Title: “Best Deal in Town!!!”
Reviews.Author: g1wzwnd
Reviews.Content: We had a perfect experience at this hotel. First of all the price was right, we paid about $190 US per night. The hotel is brand new, the staff was very nice and spoke good english, the room was great with plasma TV, fridge and an excelent shower. Breakfast in the morning was great and you can take water, soda and juices to your room for free. Room service was also very nice and the limo to the airport (brand new Mercedes) was worth the $90. We wanted to stay at the Penninsula however this hotel was very nice and highly recommended. We also book two tours with them which were great and cheap and allows you to see HK from a nice van. The only thing that needs improvement is the bed which was too hard for my taste. enjoy your stay.

Reviews.Title: “Who needs the Peninsula !?”
Reviews.Author: MrJ
Reviews.Content: Hong Kong is the classic ex-pat kind of city that believes style has to equal a fair dollop of chintz and gold. If it were not for the Felix Bar at the top of the Peninsula I can't think of a reason to pay it a visit (and actually even the bar is not that great compared to Aqua). So pushing the grand old dames of so called class and grandeur aside....I was overjoyed to fall upon Hotel JIA. Philippe Starcks involvement is obvious from the lobby entrance to the finishing touches in the rooms. Although totally unimpressive from the outside, the location is superb and therefore the price excellent. Our room was large, sexy and not a sign of chintz in sight. The hotels restaurant also happens to be one of THE hippest and coolest bars/eateries to hang out in. Being a resident also gives you access to the 'VERY DIFFICULT TO GET INTO' Kee Club (HK's version of Soho House) so the benefits are abound. Breakfast is served in a rather haphazard way in the lobby but unless you need a traditional english fry up or have a demand for specific eggs because you come from Florida and are on a bizarre diet your trainer has concocted, then muffins, tea, fruit and juice will do just fine! The staff were lovely, the vibe was fab - give it a go. If you like any Starck hotel, you will love this. If you want a view, oldey-worldy HK charm and a taxi-rank awaiting your command outside...forget it.

HotelInfo.Name: J Plus Boutique Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: No.1-5 Irving Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong, China (Formerly Jia Boutique Hotel)
